items.title: Roberta Williamsโ The Colonelโs Bequest was a different type of adventure game
items.summary: What if point-and-click games weren't about the puzzles?
items.body: Even in my youth, I always loved the idea of point-and-click adventure games more than I did the reality. I appreciated how they transported me to other worlds, each with its own rules, histories, and interesting characters. However, like many people, I often ran up against the harsh reality of solving bizarre and obtuse puzzles in a time before Internet walkthroughs. I almost never actually finished point-and-click adventure games for that reasonโbut there is one major exception: I completed Roberta Williamsโ The Colonelโs Bequest several times. One of the last Sierra adventure games to still use a text parser, The Colonelโs Bequest follows a young woman named Laura Bow as she visits a mansion in the Southern US belonging to her college friendโs grandfather, Colonel Henri Dijon. While sheโs there, a dispute breaks out over the colonelโs will, and it becomes clear a murderer is on the loose. Read full article Comments

items.title: With deadline looming, 4 of 9 universities reject Trumpโs โcompactโ to remake higher ed
items.summary: But Trump is pressuring the other five.
items.body: Earlier this month, the Trump administration made nine elite universities an offer they couldnโt refuse : bring in more conservatives while shutting down โinstitutional units that purposefully punish, belittle, and even spark violence against conservative ideas,โ give up control of admissions and hiring decisions, agree to โbiologicalโ definitions of sex and gender, donโt raise tuition for five years, clamp down on student protests, and stay institutionally โneutralโ on current events. Do this and you wonโt be cut off from โfederal benefits,โ which could include research funding, student loans, federal contracts, and even student and faculty immigration visas. Instead, you may gain โsubstantial and meaningful federal grants.โ But the universities are refusing. With the initial deadline of October 20 approaching, four of the nine universitiesโthe University of Pennsylvania , Brown , University of Southern California , and MIT โthat received the federal โcompactโ have announced that they will not sign it. In addition, the American Council on Education, which represents more than 1,600 colleges and universities, today issued a statement calling for the compact to be completely withdrโฆ

items.title: Vaginal condition treatment update: Men should get treated, too
items.summary: For bacterial vaginosis, partners are part of the problemโand the solution.
items.body: For some cases of bacterial vaginosis, treatment should include a package deal, doctors now say. The American College of Obstetricians & Gynecologists (ACOG) updated its clinical guidance Friday to fit with recent data indicating that treatment for recurring bacterial vaginosis (BV) in women is significantly more effective if their male partners are also treated at the same timeโwith both an oral antibiotic and an antibiotic cream directly onto the potentially offending member. โPartner therapy offers us another avenue for hopefully preventing recurrence and helping people feel better faster,โ Christopher Zahn, chief of clinical practice and health equity and quality at ACOG, said in a statement. Read full article Comments

items.title: Ring cameras are about to get increasingly chummy with law enforcement
items.summary: Amazon's Ring partners with company whose tech has reportedly been used by ICE.
items.body: Law enforcement agencies will soon have easier access to footage captured by Amazonโs Ring smart cameras. In a partnership announced this week, Amazon will allow approximately 5,000 local law enforcement agencies to request access to Ring camera footage via surveillance platforms from Flock Safety . Ring cooperating with law enforcement and the reported use of Flock technologies by federal agencies, including US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), has resurfaced privacy concerns that have followed the devices for years. According to Flockโs announcement, its Ring partnership allows local law enforcement members to use Flock software โto send a direct post in the Ring Neighbors app with details about the investigation and request voluntary assistance.โ Requests must include โspecific location and timeframe of the incident, a unique investigation code, and details about what is being investigated,โ and users can look at the requests anonymously, Flock said. โAny footage a Ring customer chooses to submit will be securely packaged by Flock and shared directly with the requesting local public safety agency through the FlockOS or Flock Nova platform,โ the announcement reads. items.body: Texas is being sued by a Big Tech lobby group over the stateโs new law that will require app stores to verify usersโ ages and impose restrictions on users under 18. โThe Texas App Store Accountability Act imposes a broad censorship regime on the entire universe of mobile apps,โ the Computer & Communications Industry Association (CCIA) said yesterday in a lawsuit . โIn a misguided attempt to protect minors, Texas has decided to require proof of age before anyone with a smartphone or tablet can download an app. Anyone under 18 must obtain parental consent for every app and in-app purchase they try to downloadโfrom ebooks to email to entertainment.โ The CCIA said in a press release that the law violates the First Amendment by imposing โa sweeping age-verification, parental consent, and compelled speech regime on both app stores and app developers.โ When app stores determine that a user is under 18, โthe law prohibits them from downloading virtually all apps and software programs and from making any in-app purchases unless their parent consents and is given control over the minorโs account,โ the CCIA said. โMinors who are unable to link their accounts with a parentโs or guardianโsโฆ

items.title: 12 years of HDD analysis brings insight to the bathtub curveโs reliability
items.summary: Backup firm brings a unique, informed perspective to HDD failure rates.
items.body: Backblaze is a backup and cloud storage company that has been tracking the annualized failure rates (AFRs) of the hard drives in its datacenter since 2013. As you can imagine, thatโs netted the firm a lot of data. And that data has led the company to conclude that HDDs โare lasting longerโ and showing fewer errors. That conclusion came from a blog post this week by Stephanie Doyle, Backblazeโs writer and blog operations specialist, and Pat Patterson, Backblazeโs chief technical evangelist. The authors compared the AFRs for the approximately 317,230 drives in Backblazeโs datacenter to the AFRs the company recorded when examining the 21,195 drives it had in 2013 and 206,928 drives in 2021 . Doyle and Patterson said they identified โa pretty solid deviation in both age of drive failure and the high point of AFR from the last two times weโve run the analyses.โ Credit: Backblaze Read full article Comments

items.title: Lead poisoning has been a feature of our evolution
items.summary: A recent study found lead in teeth from 2 million-year-old hominin fossils.
items.body: Our hominid ancestors faced a Pleistocene world full of dangersโand apparently one of those dangers was lead poisoning. Lead exposure sounds like a modern problem, at least if you define โmodernโ the way a paleoanthropologist might: a time that started a few thousand years ago with ancient Roman silver smelting and lead pipes. According to a recent study, however, lead is a much more ancient nemesis, one that predates not just the Romans but the existence of our genus Homo . Paleoanthropologist Renaud Joannes-Boyau of Australiaโs Southern Cross University and his colleagues found evidence of exposure to dangerous amounts of lead in the teeth of fossil apes and hominins dating back almost 2 million years. And somewhat controversially, they suggest that the toxic elementโs pervasiveness may have helped shape our evolutionary history. The skull of an early hominid. Credit: Einsamer Schรผtze / Wikimedia The Romans didnโt invent lead poisoning Joannes-Boyau and his colleagues took tiny samples of preserved enamel and dentin from the teeth of 51 fossils. In most of those teeth, the paleoanthropologists found evidence that these apes and hominins had been exposed to leadโsometimes in dangโฆ

items.title: 3 years, 4 championships, but 0 Le Mans wins: Assessing the Porsche 963
items.summary: Riding high in IMSA but pulling out of WEC paints a complicated picture for the factory team.
items.body: Porsche provided flights from Washington to Atlanta and accommodation so Ars could attend Petit Le Mans. Ars does not accept paid editorial content. The car world has long had a thing about numbers. Engine outputs. Top speeds. Zero-to-60 times. Displacement. But the numbers go beyond bench racing specs. Some cars have numbers for names, and few more memorably than Porsche. Its most famous model shares its appellation with the emergency services here in North America; although the car should accurately be โnine-11,โ you call it โnine-one-one.โ Some numbers are less well-known, but perhaps more special to Porscheโs fans, especially those who like racing. 908. 917. 956. 962. 919. But how about 963? Thatโs Porscheโs current sports prototype, a 670-hp (500 kW) hybrid that for the last three years has battled against rivals in what is starting to look like, if not a golden era for endurance racing, then at least a very purple patch. And the 963 has done well, racing here in IMSAโs WeatherTech Sportscar Championship and around the globe in the FIA World Endurance Championship. Read full article Comments

items.title: Teachers get an F on AI-generated lesson plans
items.summary: AI-generated lesson plans fall short on inspiring students and promoting critical thinking.
items.body: When teachers rely on commonly used artificial intelligence chatbots to devise lesson plans, it does not result in more engaging, immersive, or effective learning experiences compared with existing techniques, we found in our recent study . The AI-generated civics lesson plans we analyzed also left out opportunities for students to explore the stories and experiences of traditionally marginalized people. The allure of generative AI as a teaching aid has caught the attention of educators. A Gallup survey from September 2025 found that 60 percent of K-12 teachers are already using AI in their work , with the most common reported use being teaching preparation and lesson planning. Without the assistance of AI, teachers might spend hours every week crafting lessons for their students. With AI, time-stretched teachers can generate detailed lesson plans featuring learning objectives, materials, activities, assessments, extension activities, and homework tasks in a matter of seconds. Read full article Comments

items.title: Rocket Report: China launches with no advance warning; Europeโs drone ship
items.summary: Starlink, Kuiper, and the US military all saw additions to their mega-constellations this week.
items.body: Welcome to Edition 8.15 of the Rocket Report! This year has been, at best, one of mixed results for SpaceXโs Starship program. There have been important steps forward, including the successful reuse of the rocketโs massive Super Heavy booster. Clearly, SpaceX is getting really good at launching and recovering the 33-engine booster stage. But Starship itself, part spacecraft and part upper stage, hasnโt fared as well โat least it hadnโt until the last couple of months. After four Starships were destroyed in flight and on the ground in the first half of 2025, the last two missions ended with pinpoint splashdowns in the Indian Ocean. The most recent mission this week was arguably the most successful yet for Starship, which returned to Earth with little damage, suggesting SpaceXโs improvements to the heat shield are working. As always, we welcome reader submissions . If you donโt want to miss an issue, please subscribe using the box below (the form will not appear on AMP-enabled versions of the site). items.title: Yes, everything online sucks nowโbut it doesnโt have to
items.summary: Ars chats with Cory Doctorow about his new book Enshittification.
items.body: We all feel it: Our once-happy digital spaces have become increasingly less user-friendly and more toxic, cluttered with extras nobody asked for and hardly anybody wants. Thereโs even a word for it: โenshittification,โ named 2023 Word of the Year by the American Dialect Society. The term was coined by tech journalist/science fiction author Cory Doctorow , a longtime advocate of digital rights. Doctorow has spun his analysis of whatโs been ailing the tech industry into an eminently readable new book, Enshittification: Why Everything Suddenly Got Worse and What To Do About It . As Doctorow tells it, he was on vacation in Puerto Rico, staying in a remote cabin nestled in a cloud forest with microwave Internet serviceโi.e., very bad Internet service, since microwave signals struggle to penetrate through clouds. It was a 90-minute drive to town, but when they tried to consult TripAdvisor for good local places to have dinner one night, they couldnโt get the site to load. โAll you would get is the little TripAdvisor logo as an SVG filling your whole tab and nothing else,โ Doctorow told Ars. โSo I tweeted, โHas anyone at TripAdvisor ever been on a trip? This is the most enshittified websiโฆ

items.title: RFK Jr.โs MAHA wants to make chemtrail conspiracy theories great again
items.summary: It's unclear if Kennedy will follow through, but he supports the conspiracy theory.
items.body: A prominent voice in the Make America Healthy Again movement is pushing for health secretary and anti-vaccine activist Robert F. Kennedy Jr. to make the topic of chemtrail conspiracy theories a federal priority, according to a report by KFF News. KFF obtained a memo , written by MAHA influencer Gray Delany in July, presenting the topic to Calley Means, a White House health advisor. The memo lays out a series of unsubstantiated and far-fetched claims that academic researchers and federal agencies are secretively spreading toxic substances from airplanes, poisoning Americans, and spurring large-scale weather events, such as the devastating flooding in Texas last summer. โIt is unconscionable that anyone should be allowed to spray known neurotoxins and environmental toxins over our nationโs citizens, their land, food and water supplies,โ Delany writes in the memo. items.summary: Copilot expands with an emphasis on creating and editing files, voice input.
items.body: Like virtually every major Windows announcement in the last three years, the spate of features that Microsoft announced for the operating system today all revolve around generative AI. In particular, theyโre concerned with the companyโs more recent preoccupation with โagenticโ AI, an industry buzzword for โtelling AI-powered software to perform a task, which it then does in the background while you move on to other things.โ But the overarching impression I got, both from reading the announcement and sitting through a press briefing earlier this month, is that Microsoft is using language models and other generative AI technologies to try again with Cortana, Microsoftโs failed and discontinued entry in the voice assistant wars of the 2010s. According to Microsoftโs Consumer Chief Marketing Officer Yusuf Mehdi, โAI PCsโ should be able to recognize input โnaturally, in text or voice,โ to be able to guide users based on whatโs on their screens at any given moment, and that AI assistants โshould be able to take action on your behalf.โ Read full article Comments

items.title: Nation-state hackers deliver malware from โbulletproofโ blockchains
items.summary: Malicious payloads stored on Ethereum and BNB blockchains are immune to takedowns.
items.body: Hacking groupsโat least one of which works on behalf of the North Korean governmentโhave found a new and inexpensive way to distribute malware from โbulletproofโ hosts: stashing them on public cryptocurrency blockchains. In a Thursday post , members of the Google Threat Intelligence Group said the technique provides the hackers with their own โbulletproofโ host, a term that describes cloud platforms that are largely immune from takedowns by law enforcement and pressure from security researchers. More traditionally, these hosts are located in countries without treaties agreeing to enforce criminal laws from the US and other nations. These services often charge hefty sums and cater to criminals spreading malware or peddling child sexual abuse material and wares sold in crime-based flea markets. Next-gen, DIY hosting that canโt be tampered with Since February, Google researchers have observed two groups turning to a newer technique to infect targets with credential stealers and other forms of malware. The method, known as EtherHiding, embeds the malware in smart contracts, which are essentially apps that reside on blockchains for Ethereum and other cryptocurrencies. Two or more partiโฆ

items.title: Ars Live recap: Is the AI bubble about to pop? Ed Zitron weighs in.
items.summary: Despite connection hiccups, we covered OpenAI's finances, nuclear power, and Sam Altman.
items.body: On Tuesday of last week, Ars Technica hosted a live conversation with Ed Zitron, host of the Better Offline podcast and one of techโs most vocal AI critics, to discuss whether the generative AI industry is experiencing a bubble and when it might burst. My Internet connection had other plans, though, dropping out multiple times and forcing Ars Technicaโs Lee Hutchinson to jump in as an excellent emergency backup host. During the times my connection cooperated, Zitron and I covered OpenAIโs financial issues, lofty infrastructure promises, and why the AI hype machine keeps rolling despite some arguably shaky economics underneath. Leeโs probing questions about per-user costs revealed a potential flaw in AI subscription models: Companies canโt predict whether a user will cost them $2 or $10,000 per month. You can watch a recording of the event on YouTube or in the window below. Read full article Comments
